instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Intermittently working
threads.message: Hey all, had an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> come in liquid damaged. Cleaned some corrosion away from the area surrounding the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s and after that the board was working fine for a day. The next morning, went to go turn it on and it booted half way then the screen went black. Took the board back out of the case and found that every 4th or 5th time plugging in the USB-C charger it will turn on, otherwise it will sit at 4.95v 10mA. It only turns on if the SSD is removed though. Going to order in an SSD to have on hand anyway, but as far as the board goes I don't even know where to begin on something like this. Any help would be much appreciated!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Intermittently working
threads.message:
Still corrosion somewhere.
Does the machine fully boot every time SSD is removed?
Test it with USB macOS.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Intermittently working
threads.message: Looks like it isn't actually fully booting, I get no image when plugged into the display and I don't get any flashing on a USB drive plugged in. When it does hit 20v it pulls around 560mA
